Award.AwardTitle: Social Dynamics: Leveraging Online Social Networks to Shape Science Identities and Support Learning Science Concepts in Middle School Students

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract:

Social Dynamics is an exploratory project to investigate how face-to-face teaching leveraging the use of an online social network learning platform (SNLP) can increase middle school students' science learning and enhance their development of contextual identities related to science. Units from the recently developed and tested Ocean System Sciences (OSS) curriculum are the basis for the instruction. All six teachers receive professional development in the first summer and teach the OSS in year one. Testing is carried out with the same teachers in years two and three. The design-based research generates evidence about how teachers can use a Facebook-like social network platform, My Big Campus, which is currently used by school districts nationwide to complement face-to-face classroom instruction. The project investigates the ways engagement in an SNLP supports student science identity development and learning; the instructional practices that support engagement in an SNLP; how teachers use these practices to support learning and shape student science identities; and the relationships that exist between student science identities and learning within the face-to-face and SNLP contexts.

To disassociate the impacts of the SNLP and identity on learning, two teachers from Oakland Unified School District use only face-to-face instruction. One only uses science learning strategies; the other employs identity strategies in addition to the science learning strategies. In San Diego, two sets of two teachers use both face-to-face and SNLP - one set using only science learning strategies and the other set using both science learning and identity strategies. Teachers are assigned randomly to the science only and science plus identity implementations and will be separated during professional development. Twelve students, who exhibit online behaviors that stand out, are selected for in-depth interviews. The analyses requires sophisticated data tracking systems that allow for student scores to be linked over the period of one year, and students to be linked to their teachers over the course of one year.

This project should contribute to the scarce research about the effectiveness of the use of social media in science instruction.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The push for improving K-12 students’ achievement in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) is driven by a variety of reasons from developing scientifically literate citizens to cultivating the next generation of STEM professionals. In the US and UK, science in schools is failing to engage many young people. Efforts to address this dilemma come from many fronts, from policy to design of curriculum and instruction, to recognizing that learning science is not confined within the boundaries of the classroom environment or school hours. All the while networked digital technology in general have become tools for and sources of learning with which young people are comfortable and familiar. Given that these networked digital technologies are part of the “media ecology” of 21st century life, it is important for educators to understand how to use them appropriately to interact with youth and support their development. This investigation inquired how three middle school teachers used a commercially available social network learning platform, that is thus open-ended, for discourse and reflection to support learning science and developing science identities among middle school students. In this situation, it would be the teachers’ beliefs and teaching practices that drive the use of the technology’s communication capabilities to support their students.

Findings revealed that these teachers primarily used the platform as another place for whole class conversations, and blurred the boundary between in-person and online spaces for learning science. When students participated in online discussions, they transferred discourse habits from in-person conversations into the online space, both the everyday ways they spoke with one another as well as the academic discourse that their teachers were modeling and the curriculum supported. The questions that stimulated the most participation invited students to share their opinions and personal experiences.

Students’ backgrounds do predict how they converse about how they identify with science, technology, math and engineering. And while students’ attributes are less likely to contribute to the amount and structure of overall content discussions, it is possible that within-class support of students’ interests could lead to both a greater widening of topics of conversation, and ultimately help them find ways to identify with science, engineering, math and technology. When classes are large, teachers might want to either support the generation of more specialized subgroups or subconversations (which allows them to generate their own identity as a group within class) or they might try to help students generate more reciprocated discussions Dynamics of these online discussion change throughout the year, there are going to be ebbs and flows. And initial efforts will be more cohesive and then conversations with spread out some and then perhaps greater interaction will occur again. Teachers should be aware of this natural flow and, rather than try to maintain high levels of engagement all year, might try to find ways to diversify conversations, support students’ identifying with science in different ways, and to support subgroups or side conversations to work with this natural flow.

In sum, these findings offer three key insights on bringing networked digital technology into middle school science classrooms. (1) External barriers to technology integration can cascade, which potentially constrain how teachers fully use the platforms. (2) There is information lost and gained in in-person and online discussions, and that new and different skills are needed. Current strategies and techniques for facilitating productive discourse in in-person conversations involve tacit skills that are perhaps not preparing teachers for the information available from online platforms. (3) Students can transfer discourse habits learned from teacher facilitated conversations and curriculum supported tasks. Deliberate scaffolding from the classroom is needed to nudge students’ behavior online towards more productive discourse.
